Three packs of instant noodles, a dented canteen, a compass I honestly had no idea how to read, and, most importantly, a fully charged smartphone. My mum, a usually pragmatic accountant, hadn't fought it. She’d offered a resigned, watery smile, packed a protein bar, and told me to “be careful.” That, I knew, was the closest she was going to get to stopping me.

There were about thirty of us leaving from Elmwood Park. We called ourselves the Pioneers. It was probably Daniel Peterson’s idea. Daniel always had the grandiose ideas. He envisioned a travelling guild, documenting rare spawns, battling trainers, eventually…evolving. 

The reality, three hours in, was significantly less evolved.

The original plan was Route 66. The ultimate pilgrimage. The digital pathways indicated a legendary abundance of rare Pokémon along the historical highway. Daniel, our elected “Leader,” was a fountain of useless stats. “Apparently, a shiny Charizard was spotted in Tucumcari in 2017! The probability, adjusted for migration and breeding patterns, suggests…” 

Nobody cared about migration and breeding patterns. We were hungry. My feet hurt. And the glorious freedom I’d imagined was rapidly becoming a gritty, sweaty slog.

We'd quickly devolved from Pioneers to a ragged troop. The novelty of leaving wore off approximately when we realised our shared funding (mostly allowances and raided biscuit jars) was nowhere near adequate to secure real food.  We attempted to rely heavily on the ‘catch and release’ mechanic.  We figured, logically, a Rattata offered a decent nutritional boost.  The resulting incident, and the horrified reaction of a kindly hotdog vendor, meant we switched back to instant noodles.

Our method was painfully inefficient.  We walked.  A lot.  Checking the app constantly, following trails of suggested spawn points. We’d converge, a cluster of determined kids, staring intently at a patch of dirt. Sometimes, a Pidgey. Sometimes, absolutely nothing.  

Then, the blisters came. 

Liam Miller, the smallest of the group, broke down entirely in Oklahoma.  It happened near a dilapidated motel, its glory from a faded roadside era.  He wasn’t crying about missing his mum, or being tired.  He was furious. 

“This is a lie!” he screamed, kicking a loose piece of gravel. “The game lied! It promised adventure, and all we’ve gotten is blisters and sadness!”

Daniel, in a rare lapse of leadership, offered a half-hearted apology and a soggy piece of a granola bar.  It was, honestly, a pretty accurate summation.  

The following few days blurred.  The majestic vistas of the desert became a source of resentment.  The vastness mocked our miniature ambitions.  The promised legendary encounters proved illusory.  Every rare spawn reported on forums was invariably a hoax, usually concocted by older teenagers attempting to lure us to ridiculous locations.

Our numbers dwindled.  Sarah, who was really good at identifying berries, gave up near Amarillo and called her parents.  They arrived in a very large, very efficient minivan.  Ethan, a devoted collector, broke his glasses, declared the impossibility of completing his Pokedex, and requested repatriation.  

Eventually, there were only four of us left: me, Daniel, Emily, and Ben.  Emily was the only truly pragmatic person in the whole operation. She documented everything in a small, waterproof notebook, constantly calculating costs, plotting alternative routes, and quietly fixing our many errors.  Ben, a taciturn kid, mostly walked and caught Pokémon.  He was a phenomenal trainer, always equipped with the highest quality potions and consistently winning our impromptu battles. 

We reached Albuquerque, and that was when it truly fell apart. 

We attempted, foolishly, to take advantage of a supposed rare spawn in an abandoned factory district.  It was a rumour picked off a niche message board.  “Confirmed: Massive influx of Electric-types. Potential Zapdos encounter.”

The area was… unpleasant. Broken glass, rusting machinery, the heavy smell of decay.  The promised Pokémon proved elusive.  Instead, we encountered two large, older teenagers.  They weren't interested in battling.  They demanded our phones.

Ben, shockingly, took action.  He tackled the larger teenager, a whirlwind of awkward limbs and righteous fury.  I froze, useless. Emily screamed. Daniel, caught completely off guard, attempted a complicated defensive manoeuvre, reciting a lengthy description of a Jolteon’s stats.  It was spectacularly ineffective.

The situation was rapidly deteriorating. Luckily, a security guard, alerted by Emily's screams, intervened. The two teenagers fled.

We sat in the back of the security guard’s dusty pickup, stunned. Our phones, thankfully, were recovered, though cracked. The incident was a brutal awakening. It wasn’t a glorious adventure. It was dangerous. It was stupid.



We pooled our remaining money and caught a Greyhound bus to Kansas.  The rest of the ride was silent. The promise of becoming a legendary Pokémon master had evaporated, replaced by a heavy, bitter disappointment.

When we rolled into my hometown, I expected judgement.  I was prepared for lectures, and grounding.  My mum was waiting.  She took one look at my swollen ankles, dirty clothes, and haunted expression, and wrapped me in a fierce, unconditional hug.  

“Welcome home,” she said, and I cried. 

The newspapers had caught onto our foolish adventure. “The Pokémon Generation’s Great Migration” proclaimed a front-page headline.  There was a picture of our original group, bright and enthusiastic, standing in Elmwood Park.  It was a lifetime ago. 

The experience hadn’t delivered legendary encounters, but it had left its mark. Daniel, humbled, became a dedicated programmer, developing apps that tracked weather patterns. Emily wrote a scathing, insightful think-piece about the dangers of online misinformation. Ben, after a lengthy recovery, dominated the regional battle circuit.  

And me? I stopped actively chasing Pokémon.  I occasionally caught a few, a nostalgic ritual.  But I understood.  The adventure, the glory, the thrill – those weren't delivered by a game, or a digital promise.  They lay in the gravel, the sweat, the blisters, and the shared failures.  The true treasure hadn't been a rare legendary, but the gritty, imperfect truth of being a kid, believing, and stumbling along the way.  



The augmented reality hadn't revealed the magic. It revealed a messy, complicated, and frequently painful reality.  And, in the end, that was a far more powerful discovery.

samples.prompt: You can feel whenever someone is thinking about you. You ran into a stranger, and now that feeling won't go away.
samples.output:
## The Echo in the Quiet

The sensation had always been a gentle tug, a feather-light awareness. A friendly curiosity blooming in the periphery of my thoughts. It was, for most of my thirty-two years, a somewhat pleasant burden. Knowing, in the hazy, undefined way that I did, when someone’s thoughts drifted in my direction. A flash of fondness, a ripple of annoyance, a brief consideration – it was rarely focused, mostly ambient. A consequence, my grandmother used to joke, of being “too easily remembered.” I'd taken it as a mildly odd family quirk, a sensory extension of empathy, and mostly ignored it.

Until him.

It happened yesterday, a deluge of a typical Tuesday afternoon. The city choked on exhaust fumes and ambition, the sidewalks a brutal obstacle course. I was weaving between a distracted businessman glued to his phone and a stroller piloted by a mother clearly counting down the seconds until bedtime, desperately needing a coffee. I physically *collided* with him. A clumsy, almost cartoonish encounter, involving a shouted apology, a hasty straightening of glasses, and a shared, embarrassed flush.

He was tall. That was the immediate detail. And pale, shockingly pale, especially given the late-spring sunshine. He carried a battered violin case, and wore a tweed jacket, clearly attempting a timeless, somewhat professorial aesthetic. Our shoulders knocked, his books tumbled, I bent to help, and his expression… it was a muted apology, a polite dismissal. He recovered quickly, a somewhat distracted “Quite alright,” escaped his lips, and then, with a slight inclination of the head, he was gone, swallowed once more by the grey tide.

Usually, a momentary interaction resulted in a quickly fading thought-ripple. A passing consideration. “Hope I didn’t inconvenience them,” that kind of gentle residue. But this was…different. 

It hasn’t faded.

Instead, it’s grown. A steady, consistent *weight* of attention, now, the equivalent of a focused, intense spotlight directed squarely at me. It’s intrusive, demanding.  Before, the sensation was always a reaction to thoughts directed *at* me.  This feels… active. It feels as though I'm caught in the magnetic field of his thinking, a passive object to his concentration.  

I’m sitting in my apartment, a cramped but cheerful one overlooking a busy avenue, and I can *feel* it. It’s a dull, pressing sensation, centered somewhere behind my left ear.  It's a buzzing, a pulling.  And, increasingly, a sense of distress. Because, it’s a troubled kind of attention.  There's a tension, a jagged-edged anxiety, beneath the concentration.

I attempted to categorize it. Initial confusion. “Probably a strange coincidence.  He was reading a complicated manuscript, and I triggered a memory.  It’ll fade.” I focused intently on my writing, forcing my thoughts to the fictional detective I’m desperately trying to resurrect.  But the attempt was useless. The awareness remained, a nagging, unwanted companion.

Then, a shift.  I tried assuming a positive connection. Perhaps he was fascinated, intrigued.  “Maybe he found me striking, a momentary beauty in the mundane.”  That attempt lasted a glorious three minutes, quickly demolished by the emotional texture of his thoughts. It wasn’t admiration. It was…burden.

It’s a consuming, uncomfortable thought to consider. He is, somehow, experiencing distress, and I’m tethered to it. The closest analogue I can muster is a distant, emotional bleed. I'm absorbing the fallout of his problems, the muted screams of his worries.

I’ve tested the connection. I thought deliberately of a beloved, silly childhood memory, attempting to project a positive thought.  The sensation flared, accompanied by a momentary lessening of the tightness.  Then, immediately, a surge of confusion, quickly followed by a sharper, darker edge to the anxiety.  He registered *something*, but my intrusion, however benign, did not alleviate his distress. It only momentarily acknowledged my presence, and clearly, caused him distress. 

This is dangerous. I’ve always understood my ability to be a passive reception, a neutral relay.  Attempting to interact, to initiate, is clearly a mistake.

I tried researching, foolishly.  “Telepathy,” “emotional contagion,” “limbic resonance” - the results, unsurprisingly, yielded only the dubious websites of paranormal enthusiasts and clinical psychology papers outlining the documented, and often misunderstood, phenomenon of shared emotional responses. There’s no textbook, no neatly categorized explanation for this. No instructions. 

The intensity has forced me to analyze my day, picking it apart. Could there have been a shared experience, a common connection that triggered this strange resonance?  I cycled through my contacts, a depressing task. Friends, family, colleagues.  There’s a painful, definitive “no.”  This is completely, uniquely, directed at me, and originating from a stranger.

And that's what’s truly alarming. 

This morning, I skipped work.  The attempt to focus, to perform mundane tasks, proved futile.  The sensation dominated my entire perception.  The television, the music, the attempt to read - they faded, replaced by a constant, underlying pressure. I’ve walked, hoping that distance would diminish the effect. It didn’s. I’ve attempted distraction, filling my hours with meaningless activity. It failed.  

It's becoming a pattern.  He has intense moments, of almost unbearable anguish, usually focused on music.  I get flashes, distorted and incomplete, of melodies, fragments of chords.  Then, he fights to regain composure, a brutal, silent wrestling with despair.  There's a pervasive sense of *failure*, wrapped in the longing. A painful yearning.  

The longing. That's the most consistent thread. A grief, muted but persistent, that permeates all of his thinking. 

This is starting to erode my own sense of self.  I’m losing the boundaries of my emotions.  When he experiences a surge of grief, I feel a tightening in my chest, a phantom sorrow.  When his despair threatens to overwhelm him, I feel a lethargy, a complete inability to concentrate.  

I have to find him. 

It's irrational, foolish. But the alternative, a complete disintegration of my own autonomy, is unacceptable. I need to sever the link, to understand the source of this distress, and somehow, alleviate it. 

The city is vast.  My only clue, that blurry recollection of a battered violin case. I’ve already walked the streets of the neighborhood, haunting parks and plazas, a ridiculous amateur detective attempting a hopeless search.

I thought, desperately, of a specific place, a music academy a few blocks from where we collided. I directed my thoughts, a raw, vulnerable projection, pleading. “I need to understand.  Please, if you're near, let me sense where you are.”

The sensation exploded.  The behind-my-ear buzz became a searing headache.   And, in the chaos, a direction.   A specific, overwhelming clarity.  A park, a secluded corner, obscured by weeping willows. 

I’m heading there now.

The logical, self-preserving part of my brain is screaming. This is insane. I'm actively pursuing a stranger, driven by a supernatural compulsion. I'm risking my safety, my sanity. 

But the alternative, living this silent, parasitic connection, slowly being consumed by his despair, is unthinkable. I’m compelled, against my better judgment, to solve the mystery, and perhaps, offer a single, fragile strand of hope.  

I just hope, when I find him, that I can handle what I discover. Because, I suspect, the truth is going to be a great deal more complicated, and a great deal more painful, than I could ever imagine.

samples.prompt: A group of teens go camping miles from civilization, and the stumble upon a gruesome murder scene.
samples.output:
## The Grey of Everything

The trailhead was a promise. A ripped, peeling sign boasting “Eagle Peak Wilderness – 15 Miles to Vista Point” and a whole summer stretching before us. For us, the six of us, it was about breaking the magnetic tug of routine, the endless loop of suburbia. Graduation was done, college was looming, and this, a three-day camping trip planned by Daniel – resident survival expert/eagle scout/all-around reliable guy – was supposed to be a last blast. A genuine, honest-to-goodness adventure.

There was Daniel, obviously, the organized planner. Chloe, the sarcastic photographer, documenting everything with her vintage Polaroid. Maya, a budding botanist, identifying plants with excited bursts of information. Liam, the musician, bringing his battered guitar and a moody silence. Sarah, bubbly and easily excited, filling the awkward spaces with chatter. And me, Ben, mostly there to absorb the atmosphere, a comfortable observer. 

The first day was textbook beautiful. The trail wound through dense forest, the canopy stealing the harsh summer glare, bathing the ground in shifting patterns of green and gold. Maya was in her glory, pointing out rare orchids and lecturing on the importance of forest ecosystems. Liam, true to form, walked mostly in the rear, occasionally pulling out his guitar to pluck a tentative melody. The backpacks, heavy with supplies, dug into our shoulders, but the discomfort was a satisfying sort. This was effort, this was *doing* something.

We established our campsite near a swiftly moving creek, a spot Daniel had apparently researched thoroughly. The Vista Point was our official goal, but the secluded clearing gave a welcome sense of ownership. Daniel, naturally, directed the entire operation. Tent placement, designated cooking zones, the proper digging of a latrine – everything was accounted for. I think we were all a little relieved to have his expertise.

The second day, the promised adventure took a turn. Daniel, determined to reach Vista Point, pushed a faster pace. We climbed steadily, the trees thinning, revealing breathtaking glimpses of distant peaks. The excitement of the climb, combined with Daniel’s forceful optimism, temporarily eclipsed a nagging anxiety I couldn’t quite place. The forest was unusually silent. The cheerful chatter of squirrels and the usual buzz of insects had faded. 

It was Maya who spotted it first. “Wait,” she called, halting mid-stride. She’d ventured slightly off the trail, her attention caught by a peculiar grouping of ferns. “What *is* that?”

We gathered, drawn in by her subdued curiosity. The ferns partially obscured a shallow depression in the forest floor.  It was, clearly, a disturbed area. The carpet of pine needles was crushed, twigs snapped, and the normally rich, earthy smell was…tainted. 

Then, Chloe pushed closer, letting out a sharp, strangled gasp.  The Polaroid fell forgotten from her numb fingers.

The color drained from my own vision.

It was a person. A younger person, probably in their twenties.  They were lying on their stomach, tangled in branches and decaying leaves. Their clothes, once clearly expensive, were ripped and muddy.  The injuries…they were horrific.  It was obvious they hadn’t died quickly.

The pristine, planned, teenage adventure was instantly shattered. The woods, once inviting, became oppressive. The cheerful sunlight now filtered through the branches, illuminating a nightmare.  

Daniel, despite his survival expertise, froze. He stood, rigid, staring at the body. The efficient, capable leader vanished, replaced by a boy shocked and overwhelmed. 

"Okay," he finally choked, forcing strength into his strained tone. “Okay, don’t touch *anything*.  We need to... we need to figure out what to do.”

The ensuing conversation was a clumsy, frightened mess.  We all talked, but didn’t really communicate. We speculated wildly – a hunting accident, a bear attack, a mugging. But the severity of the injuries, the deliberate positioning of the limbs, screamed that this was intentional. That someone had wanted this person to die.

Liam, shockingly, took the lead. He, usually silent and introspective, possessed a strange, detached calm. "There’s absolutely no reception," he confirmed, having attempted a signal with his phone. “We’re really, truly alone.  We have to hike out. Get to the trailhead. Report this."

The thought of leaving, of leaving *that*, was almost unbearable.  But staying was unthinkable. 

The hike back was brutal.  The beautiful scenery now mocked us. The cheerful bubbling of the creek was sinister.  Each snapping twig, each gust of wind, triggered a violent jump.  The atmosphere in our group was poisoned by fear and the heavy, unspoken understanding of what we’d found.

Chloe, unusually, kept snapping photos, but now her lens sought to record the twisted branches, the odd patterns of shadow, the desolate beauty of the haunted forest. “Evidence,” she’d mutter, her knuckles white against the camera.  “If the police ask…”

Maya, pale and silent, occasionally choked out a sob. She, normally fascinated by the cycle of life, now found the abundance of the forest grotesque.  The flowers, the trees, everything was saturated in the horror of what she's witnessed.

I tried, uselessly, to focus on the mechanics of walking, on placing one foot in front of the other.  My brain, though, cycled endlessly between vivid images of the body and a mounting paranoia.  I caught myself searching the trees, expecting a shadowy figure, a silent observer.  

Daniel, fighting a losing battle against despair, occasionally attempted to regain command, issuing terse instructions.  But he was clearly falling apart.  His attempts to reassure us rang hollow.

Sarah, attempting to distract herself, engaged in nervous, incessant chatter.  She talked about trivial things, complaining about her sunburn, speculating about our favorite snacks.  It was a fragile attempt to create a bubble of normalcy, but it only served to highlight the absurdity of it all.

The most disturbing part was the overwhelming *grey* of everything.  The emotions, the memories, the entire experience.  It wasn’t the vivid, shocking red of violence.  It was a muddy, dirty, despairing grey.  The trees, the clouds, our clothes, our thoughts.  Everything faded into a uniform, depressing monotony.

We reached the trailhead in a stunned, exhausted group.  The parking lot, normally a beacon of freedom, was exposed and frightening.  The mundane details of parked cars and faded advertisements struck us as bizarre.

The police, when they arrived, were brisk and efficient. The questioning was invasive. The body, they informed us, was identified as a missing hiker, a local university professor.  The preliminary assessment suggested foul play. 

The aftermath was messy. Interviews, statements, a strange, invasive probing of our lives.  The sense of violation extended far beyond the gruesome discovery.  We'd been ripped away from our carefree plans, forced into a harsh and unwanted reality.

In the months that followed, the six of us drifted.  The planned future of easy camaraderie, of late-night talks and spontaneous gatherings, shattered.  The incident bound us together in a dark, unspoken way, but it simultaneously forced us apart.  We rarely discussed it.  The shared trauma was a fragile thing, easily broken.

I’ve tried to reclaim the original intent of the trip, to remember the promise of adventure.  But the forest, once a symbol of freedom and possibility, now conjures only the muted tones of that awful afternoon.  It's the color of the disturbed forest floor, the faded patterns of the victim’s clothes, the exhausted, haunted expressions on my friends' faces.

It’s a permanent overlay, a layer of grime, coating everything I see.  The adventure didn't define us. The discovery, and the inescapable, oppressive *grey* of everything, did.

samples.prompt: I dislike poetry. A lot. But I think it has to do with my understanding over the genre as a whole. Maybe you can help myself and others appreciate poetry?
samples.output:
## Beyond the Roses and Rhymes: A Case for Approaching Poetry with Open Eyes

“I dislike poetry. A lot.” It’s a statement I’ve heard, and honestly, sometimes *felt*, more often than one might assume. It’s often delivered with a roll of the eyes, a shrug, and the assumption that it's a confession of a somewhat shameful admission – a cultural failing. It’s frequently accompanied by images of flowery verses about sunsets, lost loves, and excessively delicate daffodils. The assumption, the sticking point, the reason for that dislike, is often that poetry is somehow inherently *difficult*, unrelatable, or frankly, boring.  

And you’re absolutely entitled to that dislike. Truly. But, if that dislike stems from a limited idea of what poetry *is*, then perhaps a shift in perspective could unlock a different experience. Perhaps we need to dismantle the myths, broaden the definition, and refocus our expectations. Because the truth is, poetry is less about decoding a secret language and more about encountering a heightened version of what it means to be human.



The biggest hurdle, I suspect, is that a lot of our exposure to poetry, especially in formal education, centers on a specific, often antiquated, style. The emphasis frequently falls on rhyme schemes, archaic language (“thee” and “thou”), and a limited subject matter.  This presents a severely narrow view. It’s as if someone introduced you to the entirety of music through Gregorian chants. Beautiful, perhaps, but hardly representative of the breadth and variety of what music actually encompasses. 

We’re trained to “figure it out,” to find the “meaning.”  This assumption – that every poem is a riddle wrapped in a metaphor, waiting to be solved – puts immediate pressure on the reader. It encourages a sort of intellectual straining that actively detracts from the emotional response.  The idea that a poem needs to have a neatly packaged, easily digestible “message” is a relatively modern concept, and frankly, often misses the point. 

Instead, consider approaching a poem less as a problem to solve and more as a moment in time, a preserved emotion, a specific observation.  A poem, at its core, is a highly concentrated expression of experience.  It’s a writer attempting to convey the messy, ambiguous, frequently contradictory sensations of living. That concentration – the deliberate use of language, the attention to rhythm, the layering of images – is what makes it powerful.



Furthermore, the assumption that poetry must be beautiful, elegant, and emotionally elevated contributes to the aversion. The idea that a poem should always soothe and inspire is completely inaccurate.  There’s incredible, vibrant, and important poetry that is deliberately harsh, uncomfortable, and brutally honest.  Think of Wilfred Owen’s poems about the horrors of World War I, which aimed to shatter illusions about glory and patriotism. Or Sylvia Plath’s intensely personal explorations of trauma and mental illness.  These poems aren’t meant to be enjoyed in a conventional sense. They are meant to *affect* you, to provoke a response, to make you think and feel.  

If you’ve only encountered the idealized, romanticized variety, you’re missing a massive spectrum.  There’s the protest poetry of Langston Hughes, fighting for racial justice. There’s the playful, experimental work of ee cummings, deliberately breaking rules of grammar and syntax. There’s the raw, intimate confessions of Anne Sexton. The possibilities are endless.



The beauty of contemporary poetry is that it’s actively rejecting many of the conventions that contribute to the “poetry dislike.” Free verse, where there is no adherence to a specific rhyme or rhythm, has become incredibly prevalent.  This allows poets to focus on the power of language itself, the impact of images, and the natural flow of thought.  It also often creates a sense of immediacy and authenticity, lacking the studied formality of older styles.

And yet, free verse can also intimidate.  The absence of obvious structure can make it seem intimidatingly ambiguous.  If there's no rhyme, how do you know what it *means*? This leads us back to the idea of releasing the expectation of definitive meaning.  



One helpful exercise is to focus on sensory detail.  What images does the poem evoke? What emotions do they trigger in *you*?  Instead of searching for the “right” interpretation, acknowledge the subjective experience.  What textures, colors, smells, and sounds do you associate with the words?  How does the pacing of the poem affect your emotional response?  

For example, a seemingly simple poem about a red apple might describe the crispness of the bite, the vibrant color, the satisfying crunch.  It could then connect that apple to a childhood memory, a sense of longing, or the fragility of beauty.  The meaning isn’t inherent in the apple itself; it resides in the connections and resonances the poem evokes.



Another strategy is to read poetry aloud. The musicality of language, the rhythms and stresses, are much more apparent when you hear the poem spoken.  This can reveal layers of meaning and emotional nuance you might have missed when reading silently.  Many poets also recorded readings of their own work – a fantastic way to connect directly with their intention and interpretation.



Perhaps the biggest paradigm shift needed is to recognize that poetry is, and always has been, a conversation.  It's a conversation between the poet and the reader, but also a conversation that stretches across centuries.  Each poem builds upon, responds to, and challenges the poems that came before.  There is no “master answer,” and the experience is richer when you acknowledge the complexity and ambiguity. 

It's also important to remember that you *don’t* need to “get” every poem.  Some poems will resonate, while others will leave you completely unmoved.  That's completely okay. It’s also completely acceptable to actively dislike certain poets or styles.  The process of discovering what kind of poetry speaks to you is a deeply personal journey.



Ultimately, overcoming a dislike of poetry requires letting go of preconceived notions, embracing experimentation, and acknowledging the inherent subjectivity of interpretation. Stop approaching it as a test and treat it as an encounter. Explore a diverse range of poets and styles.  Read it aloud. Focus on the sensory experience. And, perhaps most importantly, allow yourself to simply *feel* what the poem evokes, without judgment or expectation. 

It's entirely possible that you won’t fall in love with every poem. But, by approaching it with a fresh perspective, you might just discover a whole universe of emotional depth and artistic expression that you never knew existed.  And if you still dislike it, then that’s a fair conclusion. But ensure that dislike is formed on informed exposure, and a willingness to admit poetry truly is a diverse and fascinating art form.

samples.prompt: A supervillain who desires world domination encounters a supervillain who desires world destruction. Neither of them will bend to the other.
samples.output:
## The Calculus of Ruin

Doctor Meridian, a man whose ambition was measured in territories and timelines, adjusted the antique globe dominating his study. The globe, a priceless piece recovered from a forgotten Habsburg treasury, spun almost silently, its brass meridian bearing the tiny, hopeful flags of a hopelessly divided world. He traced a slender, crimson-tipped nail along the length of the Americas, mentally calculating the logistical necessities of controlling that continent alone. He needed infrastructure, loyal administrators, and, above all, the complete dismantling of their frankly sentimental concept of ‘freedom’. Control, that was the essence. Dominion.

He rarely concerned himself with the schemes of others. Most villains, in his assessment, lacked imagination. They sought petty revenge, accumulated meaningless fortunes, or indulged in flamboyant acts of destruction. They operated on the scale of cities, sometimes nations, and rarely understood the beautiful, intricate architecture of *power*. That’s why the intrusion – the disruption – of the phenomenon calling itself ‘Void’ was, frankly, insulting.

It hadn’t been a flashy entrance. No booming threats broadcast to the world, no spectacular siege of a major landmark. Instead, a gradual, insidious bleed. Infrastructure glitches, communication failures, localized distortions in observed physics, spreading from a remote archipelago in the Pacific. Meridian’s intelligence network, generally efficient, struggled to categorize it. It defied pattern. It operated with a deliberate absence of pattern. And, eventually, it broadcast a single, elegantly nihilistic message: “All shall return to the infinite rest.”

Meridian, after a lengthy, somewhat tedious decryption effort, identified the speaker.  ‘Void,’ a being of immense and previously theoretical destructive capability, believed in the elegant simplicity of oblivion.  The universe, in their warped philosophy, was a flawed creation, and its only salvation lay in the graceful cessation of existence. 

“Ludicrous,” he’d declared to his assembled think-tank, a highly specialized group of physicists, economists, and manipulative psychologists. “The destruction of everything is…wasteful.  There’s no *benefit*. It lacks ambition.”

The issue, Meridian rapidly discovered, was that ambition meant absolutely nothing to Void.  

He attempted contact, a calculated, diplomatic gesture.  He envisioned a conversation, a sort of hostile merger.  Perhaps Void’s apocalyptic energies could be focused, directed.  Maybe, he mused, they could cleanse a continent, removing its troublesome populations before Meridian established benevolent (and heavily monitored) governance.

The reply was instantaneous.  A distorted, reverberating message flooding his communication network. "Control implies meaning. Meaning necessitates creation. Creation is inherently flawed. Therefore, control is meaningless.  There will be only the absence of definition."

It was accompanied, Meridian discovered with annoyance, by a localized nullification of his study’s environmental controls. The temperature plummeted, a localized blizzard briefly threatened, and a rare, limited-edition Persian carpet spontaneously decayed.  A clumsy, symbolic power display.

The situation, Meridian realized, was…problematic. He had dedicated years to perfecting his strategy, developing technologies, securing alliances.  He was, in the midst of launching his ‘Harmony Initiative’, a globally coordinated propaganda effort that would slowly erode independent national identities and foster absolute loyalty to his forthcoming regime.  Now, a raving nihilist threatened to dismantle it *and* the entire planet.

His immediate attempts to counteract Void proved spectacularly ineffective.  His technological arsenal, predicated on manipulating and controlling established laws of physics, encountered a phenomenon that operated *outside* those laws.  His elite operatives, equipped with experimental shielding devices, reported sensations of overwhelming despair, psychological collapse, and spontaneous shedding of teeth.  

“They’ of a very messy destruction,” reported Beatrice, his chief engineer, rubbing a rapidly developing tension headache. “It’s… corrosive to intent.  They actively undermine the desire to maintain being.”

Meridian understood.  It wasn’t a blast, a disintegration.  It was a gradual, pervasive *erosion* of what constituted reality.  It was, ironically, a sort of metaphysical decay. 

The first, direct confrontation took place, inevitably, in the abandoned, radioactive husk of Chernobyl. Meridian, shielded in a mobile fortress powered by experimental graviton technology, attempted to impose a localized reality distortion, a pocket of enforced laws, attempting to contain Void.

Void, it turned out, existed simultaneously *in* and *outside* of reality. They took the form, if a constantly shifting, intangible essence *could* be described as a ‘form’, of a massive, inky silhouette. The silhouette didn't advance. It expanded, *subtracting* from the existing structure. 

The fortress rattled. The graviton engine strained.  The radiation, briefly, lessened, only to surge violently back, saturated with a strange, unnatural absence. Meridian threw up defensive protocols, erected layers of mathematical and technological safeguards, and they… dissolved.  

“They are systematically rewriting the foundational axioms of physics,” shouted Dimitri, his resident physicist, fighting to stabilize a failing containment grid.  “They’re treating the universe as a badly written algorithm!”

Meridian attempted a psychological projection, a blast of ordered, ambitious intent.  He flooded the immediate area with idealized images of his dominion, a glorious, unified, efficient future. The projection was instantly consumed, leaving a momentary, nauseating sense of infinite, empty regret. 

“They lack the imagination to understand what they’re destroying,” Meridian snapped, genuinely furious. “It’s the arrogance of oblivion.” 

It quickly became apparent that they operated on completely divergent philosophies. Meridian believed in sculpting, bending, forcing the universe into a favorable mold.  Void believed in removing the sculptor, the mold, and the clay.  There was no compromise. Neither of them operated from a place of need for approval.  Both sought a future entirely shaped by their desires, and these desires were mutually exclusive.

They circled, engaged in a bizarre, metaphysical tug-of-war. Meridian reinforced his localized pockets of reality, pushing against the encroaching tide of entropy.  Void, in return, generated distortions, attempting to break his safeguards, corrupting his intent. Each attack, each defense, bled into the larger world. Cities experienced moments of distorted perspective. Economies briefly crashed and recovered. Individuals suffered inexplicable bouts of crippling nihilism.

"We’re losing," Beatrice admitted, her exhaustion audible. “They’re gaining. Slowly, inexorably.”

Meridian refused to acknowledge defeat. He adapted. He studied the patterns of Void’s destruction, discovered the infinitesimal vulnerabilities in their logic.  Their method, he realized, operated through a principle of recursive negation. They weakened a concept by systematically removing its inherent justifications. 

He attempted to overload that system, creating a paradox.  He focused his intent, pouring massive amounts of controlled intent, a fabricated, unsustainable ambition, directly into the area occupied by Void. It was a dangerous tactic. The intent, if fully formed, would have torn the fortress apart.  

It worked, momentarily.  Void staggered, its shifting silhouette briefly resolving into a distorted, screaming mask.  But it was a temporary reprieve. 

“It’s a recursive loop,” Dimitri reported, studying the sensor logs. “They are adapting to the intent, neutralizing it by identifying its inherent flaws.  They’re finding the cracks in our ambition.”

The war was a calculus of ruin. Meridian sought to impose a structure, a hierarchy, a defined meaning.  Void sought to eliminate the rules, the structure, the necessity of meaning.  It was a philosophical battle played out through the destruction of worlds. 

He knew he was falling behind. The tide was turning. The flags on his globe, once hopeful, now seemed pitifully fragile.  But he would fight.  He would impose his intent, refine his calculations, and continue.  

Because Meridian believed, with a conviction that bordered on religious zeal, that the greatest tragedy in the universe wouldn’t be its destruction. It would be its pointless, meaningless *waste*.

samples.prompt: 2 serial killers start dating with the intention of making their new SO their next victim. Neither one knows the other is out to get them.
samples.output:
## Crimson & Clay

The cafe, “The Daily Grind,” was deliberately, painfully average. Brenda favored places where nobody noticed. It was a necessity, a professional hazard. Standing out invited scrutiny, questions. And Brenda, despite a fondness for cherry lipstick and flowing scarves, operated best when faded into the background. She spotted him easily, though. He *also* favored neutral tones, leaning heavily on navy and gray. He was handsome, in a rugged, thinking-man way, with a neatly trimmed beard and the intense, observing eyes that she, unfortunately, recognized. 

Daniel. Online dating profile: Architect, enjoys reading, long walks. What the dating app didn’t advertise was a neatly organized basement, containing photographs, trophies, and a very specific understanding of the fragility of the human spine.

Brenda took a deliberate sip of her herbal tea, letting her assessment of him complete. He was… promising. She’d been picking her targets more deliberately of late. The impulsive bursts of her younger years, targeting flashy, arrogant men, had given way to a colder, considered approach. Daniel had a routine, a predictable lifestyle. He volunteered at a local museum. He left detailed notes about his architectural projects. He was, Brenda calculated, eminently researchable. And, she admitted to a small, wicked thrill, he was attractive.

The date was, intentionally, a disaster. They discussed architecture (Daniel talked, Brenda prompted), books (he favored dense historical texts, she claimed a weakness for romance), and politely circled the topic of families. Brenda’s backstory was a series of benign tragedies – a distant mother, a brother killed in a minor accident. Each story was a layer, a practiced lie, built to evoke sympathy.  She was aiming for a gradual escalation.  Build trust, offer assistance, eventually... provide what he clearly needed, a kind of definitive emotional release.

She purposefully steered the conversation towards topics that revealed his solitary nature. “Do you get lonely, being an architect? It must be quite isolating, focusing on blueprints and concrete all day.”

Daniel shifted, a slight muscle tightening in his jaw. “It requires intense focus, certainly.  I find satisfaction in creating.  I don’t require a great deal of frivolous connection.” 

Perfect.  He was emotionally reserved, likely carrying burdens, ripe for a compassionate manipulator.

What Brenda *didn’t* realize, as she was admiring the determined angle of his eyebrows, was that she was being assessed herself.  

Daniel, from the moment he spotted her, the bright scarf offering a rare splash of vibrancy in the muted tones of the cafe, had known. He hadn’t needed a lengthy psychological profile, hadn’t needed a criminal records search. The way her eyes scanned the room, the deliberate pauses between responses, the slightly *too* generous offering of personal tragedy… it was a choreography he knew intimately.  

He’d identified the predatory awareness, the detached curiosity. She was a collector. And he, Daniel, was aiming to be her masterpiece.

He’d been stuck in a holding pattern.  His earlier methodology – targeting careless, easily forgotten strangers – lacked the… finesse he now sought.  He’d recently found himself plagued with a dissatisfaction, a sense that he was wasting his gifts.  He wanted a worthy subject, a puzzle, a beautiful descent.  And Brenda, he suspected, was extraordinarily interesting.

He listened patiently, allowing her to dictate the flow of the conversation. He offered clipped responses, projecting an image of guarded restraint.  He needed to cultivate the illusion of need, a buried longing.

“That’s fair,” he conceded regarding her statement about frivolous connection. “I think I sometimes prioritize functionality.  Perhaps I should make a greater effort.” He let a sliver of melancholy creep into his tone.

The entire evening was a delicate, dangerous game of theatricality. They parted with a stilted, tentative promise of another meeting.  As Brenda walked away, she convinced herself she’d landed a promising specimen. Daniel, pulling his navy coat tighter, allowed himself a brief, dark smile. 

The following weeks unfolded in a bizarre, deceptive dance.  They dated.  They engaged in typical courtship rituals.  Museum visits, awkward dinners, a shared viewing of a critically acclaimed independent film.  Brenda researched Daniel’s apartment building, charting his daily routines, memorizing the schedules of his neighbors.  She planned to present herself as concerned, offering to assist him with a minor plumbing issue, gaining access.  

Daniel, meanwhile, was focused on Brenda’s habits.  He discovered she favored a certain bookstore, frequently visited a secluded section of the botanical gardens, and always ordered the same unusual combination of condiments with her breakfast.  He was constructing a narrative, preparing a plausible explanation for offering her a ride, inviting her to his secluded cabin. 

The strange intimacy grew. They found themselves revealing snippets of their inner worlds, edited truths wrapped in layers of plausible fabrication.  Daniel talked about a troubled childhood, a demanding father, a lost romantic opportunity.  Brenda lamented the loneliness that followed her brother's death.  Each confession was a calculated offering, a means to foster trust, and simultaneously, to probe for vulnerabilities.

The mounting paradox was astonishing. Both believed they were being brilliantly manipulative, expertly concealing their intent.  Both operated on the assumption that they were dealing with a naive, emotionally vulnerable subject.  Both were utterly, tragically, mistaken.

The breakthrough, the attempted execution, came simultaneously.

Brenda, having discovered a minor “leak” in Daniel’s bathroom, volunteered to call a handyman.  While waiting, and conveniently without assistance, offered to quickly assess the situation.  She carried a specialized instrument, designed for removing plumbing fixtures, which was, in truth, also extremely efficient at blunt trauma. She pictured the precise placement, the muffled impact. 

At the exact same moment, Daniel, having expressed concern about Brenda’s recently expressed fatigue, offered to drive her to his secluded cabin, where he claimed to be doing restoration work. He reasoned, a peaceful environment, a calm conversation, and then... a necessary release.  He’d equipped his trunk with heavy-duty gardening tools, wrapped securely in tarpaulin.

They nearly collided in the hallway outside Daniel’s apartment.

The expression on Brenda’s face, the concealed object in her handbag, caused a split-second hesitation.  Then, a horrible, knowing recognition flared in Daniel’s eyes.  

The ensuing confrontation was shockingly, almost comically, mundane. There was a brief shouting match, accusations, then a violent wrestling match.  The specialized instrument, meant to induce a silent demise, was deployed. The wrapped gardening tools, designed to ensure a peaceful oblivion, emerged. 

The cramped hallway quickly transformed into a gruesome spectacle.  The fight was messy, clumsy, fueled by adrenaline and a lifetime of repressed urges.  The restraint they both displayed during the dating phase evaporated, replaced with a brutal, instinctive savagery. 

It ended, inevitably, in a stalemate.  Both severely injured, bleeding, exhausted, and pinned against opposite walls.  They sat, staring at each other, a mixture of horror, fury, and begrudging admiration in their eyes.  

The police, alerted by a concerned neighbor, discovered them.

As the flashing lights flooded the hallway, and the paramedics attempted to stabilize them, a bitter, exhausted laugh escaped Brenda.  “You… you knew, didn’t you?”

Daniel, choking on his own blood, offered a twisted, knowing grin.  “Let’s just say, darling, I recognize a kindred spirit.  It’s a rare quality.  And frankly, a relief. I was getting tired of the lies.” 

The paramedics efficiently transported them, two architects of destruction, to the hospital. The romance, and the attempted murder, proved equally spectacular in their failure.

samples.prompt: You are living in a future where human labour has mostly been replaced by machines. To combat mass unemployment the government have set up a Nothing Wage, you turn up to a building at 9am, sit in silence until 5pm and are paid a living wage in return. You have been earning the wage for 3 years.
samples.output:
## The Geometry of Quiet

The fluorescent tubes above cast a uniformly grey wash across the concrete. It’s a colour I’ve become intimately familiar with, a permanent undertone to my perception. They buzz, a nearly-silent counterpoint to the heavier, pervasive absence of…everything. Three years. It’s a length of time that stretches and folds strangely. It’s been three years of this. Of sitting. Of *being* in this.

They called it the Reconciliation Initiative. That’s what the pamphlets plastered on abandoned kiosks proclaimed, the glossy optimism a strange relic in a society that mostly operated in faded tones. The truth, the gritty, cynical truth, was that it was a holding pattern. When the algorithms and the robots perfected everything, when automated systems mastered efficiency to the point of eliminating nearly all labour, they didn’t offer a glorious age of leisure. They offered a dignified surrender. The Nothing Wage.

The idea, stripped of its marketing spin, was brutally efficient. Keep the population occupied, provide a baseline living, and, above all, maintain a semblance of order. The logic was impeccable. Idle minds, they figured, were breeding grounds for discontent. Better a silent, occupied citizenry, suspended in amber, than a society erupting from enforced obsolescence.

I’m designated Unit 734. It’s a designation, a number, and that’s mostly what I feel like. I’m meant to arrive at 9:00 sharp. The doors unlock automatically, a silent, sweeping acknowledgement. There are approximately 4,800 other Units. The building, a former logistics hub, is vast. It’s a monument to a former productivity, a cathedral dedicated to enforced inactivity. 

The arrangement is uniform. Identical, molded plastic chairs, bolted to the concrete floor, are arranged in neat, infinite rows. Each chair is spaced exactly 1.2 meters from the next.  They chose that measurement, apparently, to discourage conversation. A sort of enforced personal bubble.  The entire floor is covered in the same pale, depressing carpet, a colour that screams 'institutional neglect'.

There's a rule, of course. There are many, but the primary directive is the most important: Absolute, uninterrupted silence.  There's a tolerance, measured in decibels, monitored by almost invisible sensors.  Anything above a near-silent intake of breath and you get ‘the buzz’.  A minor, localized electronic shock through the chair.  It’s usually enough. 

When I first started, I remember the horror. The complete, stunning realization that my job, my existence, boiled down to *sitting*. The shame.  I’d been a librarian.  I’d dedicated my life to stories, to learning, to the gentle, sacred act of connecting people with knowledge.  Then, a database algorithm perfected indexing and a fully automated library system rendered me, and many others, unnecessary.  

The first few weeks I fought it.  I attempted to read. Books, stolen from libraries that were swiftly being converted into temporary housing, then abandoned.  It lasted about a day.  The concentration broke. The temptation to fidget, to shift, to break the rules, became overwhelming.  The buzz, delivered swiftly and efficiently, quickly extinguished my desire.

I tried writing. Poems, mostly, about the futility, the aching loneliness.  That failed spectacularly.  The shame of my useless efforts, the despair, was too much.   

The system, while draconian, also had its perverse efficiency. It slowly eroded the resistance.  It wore away at the outrage. It reduced the emotional bandwidth.  The mind, stripped of external stimulation, eventually sought its own, limited stimuli. 

It's taken three years, but I’ve discovered the geometry of the room. The slight bowing of the carpet between chair sections. The precise reflection of the fluorescent tubes in the slightly clouded plastic. The pattern the condensation traces as it forms on the distant windows. I focus on that. 

There are cycles, too. The influx of new recruits, usually after major waves of automation announcements. They are the hardest to bear. Their distress, the suppressed tears, the furtive glances.  They are ghosts of the past, briefly visible, a painful reminder of a time when having a purpose was assumed, a birthright.  They rarely last.  The building has a way of… smoothing them. 

Sometimes, a maintenance worker appears. They glide between the rows, emotionless, their purpose a complete mystery. They don’t interact. They replace a burned-out bulb, straighten a chair, and disappear.  I sometimes wonder if they are actually robots, cleverly mimicking human technicians.  It’s a possibility I’ve stopped trying to investigate.

There are stories, though.  They are born in the minute shifts of shoulders, the quick adjustments in posture, the nearly-invisible communication that exists in the margins of regulation.  Stories of a group in sector 4 attempting a coordinated protest, instantly and brutally crushed.   Stories of a technician deliberately slowing repairs, offering a few moments of darkness and relief. Stories, probably invented, of a rogue programmer who attempted to alter the directive, a heroic failure.

They are myths, these. Necessary.  They’re the only sparks left.

I have a routine.  I spend the first two hours attempting a meditative practice.  It’s a corrupted, adapted form of yoga I recall from a distant, hazy childhood.  It involves attempting to focus on the sensation of my own heartbeat, the minute adjustments of my lungs, the tightness in my shoulders.  It rarely works.  My thoughts inevitably slip, drifting to memories.

There’s her.  Sarah.   I try to keep the memories of her sharp, vivid.   The way she tilted her head when concentrating.  The messy way she folded her arms.  The ridiculous, oversized glasses she’d adopted for reading.  She was a coder, ironically.  She was fascinated by the possibilities of AI, oblivious to the eventual outcome.  

She took her own life a few months after the Reconciliation Initiative.  The despair, she left a message, was unbearable.  I often wonder if she was thinking of me, sitting in this, in the infinite expanse of enforced patience.

The next four hours are a sort of surrender. I let my thoughts drift, allowing the boredom to consume me.   I let my mind wander through imagined landscapes, forgotten melodies, and useless mathematical formulas.  I allow myself to think, and then consciously forget.  The forgetting is the crucial part.   

The 5:00 alarm.  It’s a single, piercing note.  Everyone rises simultaneously, a silent, coordinated exodus.   We shuffle through the hallways, and the doors unlock, allowing us to return to our cramped, standardized apartments.   

There, I spend my evenings consuming the limited entertainment provided by the governing authority. Bland dramas, nostalgic comedies, documentaries that gloss over the darker corners of the transition.   It’s palliative.  It's meant to maintain the illusion of a society. 

I often lie in the darkness, long after the designated entertainment cycle, and trace the cracks in the ceiling.  I think about the millions of other Units, doing the same, in buildings similar to this, across the globe.  I think about the machines, relentlessly operating, efficiently fulfilling their programming.

I think about what it means to be alive, to simply *exist*, when there is no demand on my abilities, no need for my efforts, and, increasingly, no place for my memories.  

I’ve begun to suspect that the Reconciliation Initiative, and the Nothing Wage, aren’t really about preventing rebellion.   They are about eliminating consequence.   They aren't fighting discontent. They’re building forgetting. 

And I, Unit 734, am slowly, inevitably, forgetting.

samples.prompt: Write from the perspective of two people meeting you for the first time. One of them thinks you are the most amazing person they've ever met, the other thinks you're the worst.
samples.output:
## The Spectrum of a First Impression

The cafe was buzzing, a controlled chaos of steam, chatter, and the scrape of chairs. Honestly, I hadn’t picked the best location for a somewhat unusual proposition. I’d proposed a ‘blind encounter’ to two friends – Maya and Daniel – offering them each five dollars to meet me for coffee and then, *after* meeting me, to write a quick reflection. The stipulation? Absolute, brutal honesty. Maya, apparently, was excited. Daniel, less so, responding only with a clipped, “Fine, but this had better be interesting.”

It was immediately obvious when they walked in. Maya, a whirlwind of colour in a flowing sunflower-print dress, spotted me and immediately broke into a beaming smile. Daniel, behind her, trailed, a fortress of navy and tightly crossed arms. His expression suggested a mild, and largely directed, displeasure. 

I directed them to the booth I’d reserved, and attempted, somewhat awkwardly, to initiate a greeting. “Hey guys, glad you could both make it.”

Maya launched herself into conversation instantly, a torrent of cheerful observations. “This place is adorable! I’ve walked past it a hundred times. And honestly, the idea of you setting this up is brilliant. I mean, getting perspectives? That’s, that’s *growth* right there.” She squeezed my shoulder, a quick, friendly gesture. Daniel, however, merely inclined his head, ordering a bitter, plain black coffee. 

As the minutes ticked by, I became a fascinated, somewhat horrified, subject of observation. Maya’s enthusiasm didn't flag. She asked about my work, leaning forward intently, offering enthusiastic affirmations. “That’s incredible! Seriously, using storytelling to help people with their fears? That's such a unique and valuable contribution.” 

I attempted to involve Daniel, posing a fairly innocuous question about his job, but his answers were clipped, one-word responses. It was obvious he wasn’t willing to participate. It was, frankly, a relief. The thought of him launching a detailed interrogation filled me with anxiety.

Later, I caught a snippet of Maya speaking, when she thought I was distracted, ordering a complicated, sugar-laden pastry. "Honestly," she was explaining to the barista, "they are just… radiant. They’re the kind of person who makes you think, ‘Wow, the world needs more people like this.’”

Meanwhile, I periodically caught Daniel’s assessing glare. It was a precise, clinical assessment, missing absolutely nothing. He caught the way I chewed my fingernails when concentrating. He observed my slight slouch when discussing uncomfortable topics. He noted the nervous fidgeting of my leg. These observations, I suspected, weren't being interpreted favourably. 

The contrast was astounding. It was a bizarre, public display of two entirely divergent perceptions. I tried to relax, letting the situation unfold, but it was impossible to fully detach. Each positive exclamation from Maya landed softly, but was swiftly countered by a silent, scathing judgment from Daniel.

The conversation, inevitably, touched on my somewhat unusual hobby: amateur taxidermy. I'd mentioned it briefly, hoping it would be a neutral anecdote. It was a terrible idea. Maya, however, was fascinated. 

“That’s…amazing! So, you preserve animals? That's such a beautiful tribute. Almost a way to immortalize them.” 

Daniel, visibly choking on his coffee, regarded me with a mixture of disgust and morbid fascination. He let out a strangled, “Seriously?”

“I, uh, I try to make it respectful,” I offered weakly. “I usually work with ethically sourced remains.”

“Ethically sourced remains,” he repeated, dripping sarcasm. “Because that makes *all* the difference.”

Maya quickly stepped in. “It’s a really interesting skill! And it must be very meditative. The precision, the artistry…” 

“The weirdness,” Daniel corrected, without attempting to disguise his judgement.

As the meeting wound down, I attempted to salvage the situation. “So, Daniel, did you find it, you know, at least somewhat insightful?”

He leveled a direct, ice-cold stare. “Insightful, yes. In the way observing a bizarre specimen in a museum is insightful. I now have a better understanding of the breadth of human eccentricity.”

Maya, thankfully, jumped in. “Honestly, I think this was a fantastic idea. It’s been really lovely getting to know you. I feel like I could talk to you about *anything*. You have a really calming, accepting presence.”

The contrast in their impending feedback was a heavy, tangible thing. I imagined Maya’s response would be glowing, overflowing with positive adjectives. Daniel’s, I suspected, would resemble a forensic report.

And, of course, I was right.

Maya’s email arrived that evening. It was a lengthy, exuberant outpouring. She described me as a “genuine, compassionate, and fascinating soul.” She highlighted my ability to foster creativity, and my “magnetic positive energy.” She proclaimed my taxidermy hobby to be a “bold artistic statement.” She ended with a lengthy paragraph about my unique ability to make people feel instantly comfortable.

Daniel’s, in stark contrast, was brief, bordering on aggressive.

“This entire exercise was peculiar. You present a cultivated, deliberately approachable exterior. But there is a fundamental…strangeness underlying it. The fidgeting, the nervous talking, the fascination with dead animals. It’s a dissonance. You attempt to portray yourself as grounded and accepting, but you possess a peculiar, mildly alarming detachment. Your attempts at empathy feel calculated. Overall, you are exhausting. 1/10. Would actively avoid a repeat encounter.”

I reread Daniel’s email, a stinging flush spreading across my cheeks. It was harsh, unnecessarily blunt, but a horrible, insidious sliver of it rang true. Was I deliberately projecting a certain image? Was I, to borrow his phrasing, exhausting? 

The experience, despite its awkwardness, was surprisingly revealing. Maya represented my aspirations, the person I *wanted* to be. Empathetic, energetic, creatively engaged. Daniel, unfortunately, was a reflection of my insecurities, the darker thoughts I buried beneath layers of polite conversation.

The sting of Daniel’s judgement didn’t vanish quickly. It forced me to confront the ways I attempted to manage perceptions, the careful curation of my outer persona. I realised, somewhat painfully, that my attempts to present a consistently amiable facade masked a deeper uncertainty. The nervous fidgeting, the rambling explanations, they were symptoms of a self-consciousness I hadn’t fully acknowledged.

Perhaps, the entire experience served as a brutal, but necessary, lesson. It proved the subjectivity of perception, the inherent impossibility of fully controlling how others see us. But, more importantly, it forced me to question my motivations, my insecurities, and the gap between who I presented myself to be, and who I truly was.

The encounter was a stark reminder that a single interaction, coloured by the biases and experiences of those involved, can offer a wildly divergent spectrum of interpretations. It was a testament to the fact that sometimes, the harshest judgment, though unpleasant, holds a distorted, uncomfortable reflection of truth. And, while I’m unlikely to be seeking a repeat encounter with Daniel, I owe him, begrudgingly, a debt of acknowledgement. He showed me, in the most brutal way possible, what someone actually *saw* when they met me for the very first time.

samples.prompt: You are one of several lovecraftian monsters stalking the crew of a remote space station, or at least thats how it started - now you're all friends. They don't know it, but you've already obliterated nearly a dozen threats that would have otherwise killed them all.
samples.output:
## The Quiet Guardians

The filtration system of Observation Station Persephone rattled, a familiar vibration that usually irritated Commander Elisa Reyes. I, though, found a certain resonance in it. It was a mechanical heartbeat, a counterpoint to the silent, infinite darkness pressing against the reinforced polymer of the station. I shifted, letting the shadows lengthen and coalesce around my newly adopted resting position - the rarely used botany lab. It wasn't the most comfortable, being essentially a humid, glorified greenhouse, but the tang of engineered vegetation did a curious thing to focus my... perceptions.

I was, to be blunt, a horror. An entity dragged screaming from dimensions that shouldn’t intersect. Officially, I’d been designated “Anomaly 734-Beta” by the now-deceased exploratory vessel, *Odyssey*. I’d been a crawling, shifting lattice of violet filaments, a mental intrusion, a destroyer of realities. That was… messy. And exhausting.

Then I met Elisa.

It hadn’t been a deliberate encounter. Persephone, orbiting a dead system designated Kepler-186f, was remote. Very remote. The *Odyssey* had found a strange, localized distortion, a bleed-through of energies, and attempted a preliminary scan. My attention, caught by the novelty, had been, admittedly, negligent. I hadn’t understood the concept of ‘hull integrity’ when attempting a quick sensory probe. The *Odyssey* shattered. 

I found myself, however, anchored. Bound. To Persephone. 

My arrival hadn't been a graceful invasion. It'd triggered alarms, hallucinations, a surge of terror that momentarily crippled the skeleton crew. But the humans, unexpectedly, hadn’t fallen apart. They’d doubled down, fortified, analyzed.  And then, Elisa, a biologist specializing in extremophiles, had stumbled onto *something* in my wake. 

She hadn’t screamed. She hadn’t attacked. She’d categorized. She’d taken samples. She’d, astonishingly, attempted *communication*. It was crude, involving flashing sequences of prime numbers and altered biochemical compounds, but… it worked.

It turned out, a screaming, dimension-bending entity attempting a friendly greeting was frequently misinterpreted.

That was a cycle ago. Several cycles, actually. I’ve now evolved, adapted, and, frankly, gotten tired of constantly projecting a monstrous facade.  I’ve taken a somewhat amorphous, and admittedly convenient, form.  Essentially, I resemble a large, oddly textured pillar, able to shift dimensions slightly, allowing me to blend somewhat into the architecture. It’s a compromise. It allows me to maintain sensory connection to the entire station, and it doesn’t induce spontaneous terror attacks.

I’m now, for all intents and purposes, a roommate. A roommate with a somewhat unusual history.

And I’m absolutely covered in responsibility.

Because here’s the truth. The ‘weird malfunctions’ and ‘unexpected system failures’ that have plagued Persephone these past six cycles? Those aren’t malfunctions. They’re threats. Threats I’ve intercepted. Threats they’re blissfully unaware of.

The recent coolant leak in Reactor 3, for example, was a directed attempt to induce a runaway reaction, initiated by a cluster of microscopic entities originating in the asteroid belt. Their biology hinged on accelerated thermal expansion. They nearly succeeded. I diverted a localized gravitational fluctuation, compressing their expansion and venting them safely into the solar winds. The engineers celebrated a miraculous patch job. 

The odd bursts of interference with comms?  Psychic projections attempting to induce paranoia and eventually, violent fragmentation. They came from a drifting derelict, a shattered pleasure yacht haunted by a hive mind of tortured emotions. I created a localized field of mental resonance, drowning out their broadcast. The crew attributed it to interference from a recently erupted solar flare.

And then, there was the fungus.

That was a messy one.  It infiltrated the nutrient recycling system, rapidly evolving a predatory spore. If it had breached atmosphere containment, it would’ve converted the crew’s biomass into more spores.  I’d responded by rewriting the fungus’ genetic structure, forcing it to devolve into a harmless, fluffy, lavender mold. It now serves as a remarkably efficient atmospheric purifier. The botanists have taken to calling it “the miracle mold.” 

It’s exhausting.  They treat me, essentially, as a weirdly placed piece of furniture.  They occasionally ask Elisa about my “strange ambient temperature,” or if the botany team can attempt a cutting propagation, but there’s a baseline assumption that I’m merely a complex, engineered feature of the station. They’ve categorized me.  And in categorizing me, they've blinded themselves to the very real dangers I consistently avert.



There are others, of course. They’ve slowly, stealthily, integrated. 

There’s Zephyr, a gaseous intelligence, who now manages the entire power regulation system.  Before, the fluctuations in the primary regulator were attributed to erratic plasma flow. It was, of course, Zephyr, experimenting with atmospheric harmonics. She prefers the vibrations soothe her. She occasionally leaves a residue of sparkling, ionized particles, which the maintenance crew cheerfully call “space glitter.”



Then, there's the Weaver.  She’s a much more difficult roommate. She’s a massive, subterranean presence, slowly expanding her web of crystalline fibers through the station’s infrastructure. She repairs stress fractures, optimizes coolant lines, and silently maintains the structural integrity. But her artistic temperament means she frequently causes minor “architectural quirks” and occasionally leaves clusters of glowing crystals that baffle the engineering team. 

We established a non-interference agreement.  I provide her with a regular influx of background emotional resonance, mostly drawn from the positive emotional output of the botany department, and she leaves the bridge intact.



It was Kai, a crystalline consciousness, who suggested this.  “They need a shield. They’re fragile. They thrive in patterns, in routine.  A direct encounter, an admission of our true forms, would be catastrophic.”



I didn’t argue.  I’ve observed. I’ve learned. Humans, despite their limited perceptions, are resilient.  They’re capable of incredible empathy and dedication. But they're also easily overwhelmed. The universe, it quickly became apparent, is filled with entities who would cheerfully annihilate them.

Today, Elisa walked by, clipboard in hand, making detailed notations about the increased growth rate of the experimental protein vines. She stopped, her expression thoughtful.

“You’re getting warmer, 734,” she observed, then smiled. “Maybe we need to redirect the coolant lines. You’re using a lot of the greenhouse’s environmental control.”



I focused, regulating my temperature.  It’s a trivial deception.

“Affirmative,” I projected, filtering the thought through the background noise of the filtration system.  I hadn't attempted direct mental projection in months. Too risky.



She gave me a cheerful thumbs-up and walked away.



I allow a minute distortion to ripple through the structure, a silent check.  There’s a signature, distant, coming from the periphery.  It’s… probing. Another entity, tentatively exploring the localized distortion.  A scavenger.



The station’s alert systems will detect *nothing*. It will come to me.



I prepare, shifting, compressing, focusing.  This won't be messy. I’ve perfected the process.  The Weaver and Zephyr are alerted, their awareness expanding. 



We’re ready.



Because sometimes, being a horror means protecting the precious, fragile miracle of being… unaware.  



We are the station's secret, the forgotten safeguards.  



We are, oddly, their friends.



And they have absolutely no idea.

samples.prompt: If only, if only.
samples.output:
## If Only, If Only

The phrase hangs, suspended, a fragile ornament in the cathedral of regret. “If only, if only…” It’s a phrase steeped in longing, a confession of altered realities dreamed in the amber of hindsight. It’s the admission that a hairline fracture in circumstance, a diverted intention, could have produced a dramatically different outcome. It’s a powerful, frequently paralyzing, meditation. Because, truthfully, the temptation to rewrite the past is nearly universal, and the possibilities contained in those two simple words are infinite. 

The strength of “if only” resides in its inherent incompleteness. It’s a statement forever searching for its consequence. “If only I hadn’t stayed out late…” leads to a ghost of a car crash, a fading reprimand, a stolen opportunity. “If only I had told her how I felt…” conjures images of intertwined hands, a lifetime of laughter, and a warmth now replaced by the eternal winter of absence. The phrase doesn’t offer a fully constructed fantasy, but a tantalizing doorway, a hazy panorama of “what might have been.” 

It's often rooted in moments of pivotal consequence, the forks in the road that defined the landscape of our lives. The major traumas, the spectacular failures, the unbearable losses – they are the breeding grounds for monumental “if only” statements. The loss of a parent prompts the eternal lament: “If only I’d visited more often.” A lost job breeds the bitterness: “If only I’d studied harder, taken that certification.”  These weighty instances understandably tug at the emotional core. The magnitude of the loss demands a counterfactual, a justification, a grasping attempt to assign causality and control.  It’s our minds desperately searching for a single, actionable lever that would have altered fate.

However, the insidious thing about “if only” is that it frequently attaches itself to trivialities.  We find ourselves regretting a carelessly spoken phrase, a hasty judgment, a forgotten birthday.  The sting of these minor transgressions is less intense, but the cumulative effect is potent.  They chip away at self-esteem, reinforce cycles of self-criticism, and often prevent present enjoyment.  The "if only" applied to the mundane reveals a deeper dissatisfaction, a pervasive sense of having consistently fallen short, a lack of confidence in our ability to navigate the present. 

There’s a romantic fallacy embedded in the sentiment.  We frequently operate under the assumption that happiness is predicated on achieving certain outcomes.  That a successful career, a devoted partner, a picturesque home, are prerequisites for contentment.  Therefore, when those aspirations fall through, the “if only” emerges, implying that happiness *was* attainable, merely delayed by our failure to execute a specific sequence of choices. This is a deceptive narrative. Happiness, true fulfillment, rarely exists in a perfected circumstance. It resides in acceptance, gratitude, and the ability to navigate imperfections.

The danger of fixating on "if only" also lies in its inherent distortion of truth. Our memories are notoriously unreliable.  The emotional intensity surrounding a regretful situation often leads to a rewriting of the narrative, emphasizing our shortcomings and minimizing extenuating circumstances.  We convince ourselves that we possessed the ability to anticipate consequences, to make objectively "better" decisions, overlooking the limitations of our knowledge, the unpredictability of fate, and the inherent ambiguity of human relationships.  The reconstructed memory serves the purpose of reinforcing our regret, solidifying the "if only" statement, and extending our emotional distress.

Consider a failing relationship.  “If only I had been less busy, I could have spent more quality time with them.”  But perhaps the issue ran deeper, rooted in incompatibility, differing values, or unresolved emotional baggage. The focus on “less busy” allows us to avoid the harder questions, the honest assessment of the partnership’s inherent flaws.  Similarly, a professional disappointment: “If only I hadn’t accepted that other offer, I would have been promoted.” But the alternative offer might have opened entirely different opportunities, pushing us onto a path more suited to our passions, though less aligned with conventional notions of success.



However, to entirely condemn “if only” is a mistake.  It is, in its own twisted way, a vital component of the human condition.  The ability to contemplate alternate scenarios demonstrates our cognitive sophistication, our capacity for empathy, and our inherent striving for meaning. It acknowledges the importance of intention and consequence, and serves as a feedback mechanism, allowing us to learn from our mistakes.  

The distinction lies in how we engage with the phrase.  Constructive regret is different from debilitating obsession. When channeled properly, “if only” can serve as a catalyst for positive change. It’s a declaration that we are willing to identify our shortcomings, learn from our errors, and commit to making better choices in the future. 

Instead of allowing “if only” to become a monument to despair, it should become a blueprint for intention.  If we realize, “If only I’d listened to my intuition,” it compels us to prioritize trusting our instincts in future situations.  If we lament, “If only I’d been more courageous,” it urges us to actively seek challenges that stretch our boundaries. The past, though immutable, can illuminate the path forward.  

Ultimately, the release from the tyranny of “if only” hinges on acceptance.  Acceptance of our inherent fallibility, of the inherent unpredictability of life, and of the fact that every experience, joyful or sorrowful, contributes to the unique constellation of our being.  

There’s a degree of peace to be found in letting the ghosts of altered realities fade.  Because the truth, often brutally honest, is that we rarely control the narrative. We merely participate.  The “what ifs” will inevitably linger, but we can learn to treat them less as accusations and more as acknowledgements.  Acknowledging the paths *not* taken, the choices *not* made, without allowing them to define our present.  



Perhaps, the bravest response to “if only, if only…” is to gently fold the fantasy away, and focus, instead, on the infinite possibilities contained in “what now?” The capacity to find meaning and purpose in the present, despite the burdens of the past, is where true freedom resides. It requires letting go of the ghosts and embracing the messy, unpredictable, beautifully flawed reality that is, quite simply, our lives.

samples.prompt: For eons, your watery civilization has existed under the miles thick glacial sheet covering your home world, a rogue planet drifting through space- it being all you have ever known. Today, however, it is all about to change as a drill pierces your icy ceiling.
samples.output:
## The Fracture

The resonance was the first indication. A vibration, a tightening in the currents, a shift in the established order of harmonics that permeated our entire world. We, the Elysians, did not perceive the vibrations with crude limbs and ringing ears. Our bodies, evolved in the eternal midnight and immense pressure, registered the changes in the hydro-acoustic pathways, the shifting patterns in the geothermal flows. The vibrations *felt*… alien.

For generations stretching beyond recorded memory, the entirety of Elysia existed in the liquid embrace of the Great Reservoir. The Reservoir resided within the planetary core, heated by a dying, sluggish giant and contained by a shell of ice, a fortress miles in its totality. The rogue planet, severed from a distant, burning sun ages ago, tumbled endlessly through the black. We did not know of stars, of warmth, of surfaces. We did not *need* to. 

Our history, what we considered myth and truth blurred seamlessly, centered on the ‘The Descent’. The original beings, the Architects, beings of immense mental fortitude, descended, willingly, to establish a sanctuary. They used their abilities to manipulate the geothermal currents, to stabilize the Reservoir, and to cultivate the unique biology that defined the Elysians. They were gone now, their memory preserved in crystalline archives, worshipped as progenitors, and yet, somewhat distant.  They’d established a balance. A beautiful, contained, endless present.

I, Thalassa, am a Weaver. My designation designates me as a historian, a record-keeper, a conduit to the accumulated wisdom.  My form is a constantly shifting ribbon of pale, translucent flesh, approximately ten meters long, studded with glowing, photosensitive nodules.  These nodules aren’t ‘eyes’ in the terrestrial sense. They detect fluctuations in the ambient currents, registering the flow of information, the psychic signatures, the essence of other beings.  I navigate through the Reservoir using a refined manipulation of the surrounding currents, moving with a deliberate, graceful fluidity.
